translationBlock.key: Find a bug in this page? %sEdit this page yourself, then submit a pull request.%s (Note this page is automatically generated from the documentation in the source code.)
Sorry, there are no examples for this function! :(
There are a few special predefined schedules, for very common cases:
Additionally, when using the asterisk, you may use the format "*/X" character to mean "every X <time unit>" where X is some integer. For instance:
Run once a month at midnight in the morning of the first of the month
Barring predefined special schedule definitions, a cronFormat is specified with 5 "sections", each separated by one or more space (or tabs).

Upon restart of the server (or reload) all cron jobs will be cleared out, so all tasks should be declared in a main file at startup, and probably not declared dynamically (though that is allowed). The closure will then be run at the specified interval. Just like with the actual unix program, if the server isn't running when a task "activates", it will not be activated when the next startup occurs. The process that calls set_cron must continually be running for it to activate properly.

Sets a task to occur at a regular interval, given a cron style interval. This allows for an easier way to specify that a task should happen, for instance, every hour on the hour. Unlike set_interval, this uses absolute wall clock time, not relative times. The task id is returned, so it can be cleared later with clear_cron if needed. If clear_cron is run from within the task itself, the id is optional. See more information for a detailed description of cron format.

Unlike the actual cron task, @reboot is not available. Simply run the code in a main file for similar behavior. Additionally, the slash "/" is only available for use with the asterisk (*/X). The L, W, ? and # characters in day of week are not supported.
Run once a day at midnight

Means run at one minute past midnight, every day of the month, every month of the year, and every day of the week. In addition to single numbers, comma separated numbers may be used, as well as ranges.
Run once a week at midnight in the morning of Sunday
Run once an hour at the beginning of the hour
Run once a year at midnight in the morning of January 1
means to run the task every 30 minutes.
means to run on the hour, and on the half hour.
If a star is present in each position, it means that it will trigger regardless of what the current date/time for that segment is. For instance:

The format used here is very similar to the Unix program cron, however, a few features are missing, as they aren't useful in the context of this function. For a brief overview of the Unix tool cron, see here: %s However, information for this function specifically is below.
